intro: Micromeles malayensis, commonly known as the Malay mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant native to Southeast Asia. It belongs to the family Viscaraceae and typically grows on the branches of host trees, such as those in the Dipterocarpaceae family. The plant has small, elliptical leaves that are usually opposite in arrangement, and it produces small, white or yellowish flowers. Its berries are fleshy and serve as a food source for various birds and animals, aiding in seed dispersal. Micromeles malayensis plays a role in the ecological dynamics of its habitat by influencing host tree health and supporting local wildlife.
